g.text: appear macroscopically homogeneous, while their surface color appears to be visually uniform and intermedi-
ate between those of the crystalline and the metallic glass coupons. The coupon surface color from left to right
appears to transition from the pale-gold color of the monolithic metallic glass to the yellow-gold color of the
primary-Au alloy. That is, the MGMCs appear to display an increasingly yellower color as
0, reflecting the corresponding decrease in the molar (or volume) fraction of metallic glass phase from 100% to 0.
The CIELAB color coordinates of the 20 mm
1 mm plate coupons are measured in color space
by an optical spectrophotometer on the plate coupons (see Methods). The measured CIELAB coordinates are
listed in Table S2 (see Supplemental Information). The CIELAB coordinates of the primary-Au Au
are consistent with a yellow color, and falls within the “yellow” region of the Au-Cu-Ag color map (see Fig. S1,
Supplemental Information). This demonstrates that the color of the primary-Au phase in the MGMCs is fixed
by the choice of the Ag and Cu concentrations to a custom yellow color. In principle, by choosing different Cu
and Ag concentrations one may potentially achieve any color in the Au-Cu-Ag color map. On the other hand, the
CIELAB coordinates of the monolithic metallic glass Au
are consistent with a pale white color.
X-ray diffractograms revealing the atomic structure of the primary-Au, MGMC, and metallic glass
. The diffractograms verify the amorphous structure of the metallic glass phase
, the primary-Au structure of the particulate phase alloy Au
composite structure of the MGMC alloys Au

for each alloy are indicated by arrows.
between the monolithic metallic glass and MGMC alloys, but
rises considerably as the alloys transition from a
pure metallic glass phase to a pure primary-Au phase.
